sn3.22:1.2: King Pasenadi of Kosala sat to one side, and the Buddha said to him,
sn3.22:1.3: “So, great king, where are you coming from in the middle of the day?”
sn3.22:2.1: “Sir, my grandmother has passed away. She was old, elderly and senior. She was advanced in years and had reached the final stage of life; she was a hundred and twenty years old.
sn3.22:2.2: But I loved my grandmother; she was dear to me.
sn3.22:2.3: If by giving away the elephant-treasure I could get my grandmother back, I’d do it.
sn3.22:2.5: If by giving away the horse-treasure I could get my grandmother back, I’d do it.
sn3.22:2.7: If by giving away a prize village I could get my grandmother back, I’d do it.
sn3.22:2.9: If by giving away the whole country I could get my grandmother back, I’d do it.”
sn3.22:2.11: “Great king, all sentient beings are liable to die. Death is their end; they’re not exempt from death.”
sn3.22:2.13: how well said this was by the Buddha:
sn3.22:2.14: ‘All sentient beings are liable to die. Death is their end; they’re not exempt from death.’”
sn3.22:3.1: “That’s so true, great king! That’s so true!
sn3.22:3.2: All sentient beings are liable to die. Death is their end; they’re not exempt from death.
sn3.22:3.3: It’s like the vessels made by potters. Whatever kind they are, whether baked or unbaked, all of them are liable to break apart. Breaking is their end; they’re not exempt from breakage.
sn3.22:3.4: In the same way, all sentient beings are liable to die. Death is their end; they’re not exempt from death.”
sn3.22:3.5: That is what the Buddha said. …
sn3.22:4.3: They pass on according to their deeds,
sn3.22:4.4: reaping the fruits of good and bad.
sn3.22:4.5: Those who do bad go to hell,
sn3.22:4.6: and if you do good you go to heaven.
sn3.22:5.1: That’s why you should do good,
sn3.22:5.3: The good deeds of sentient beings
sn3.22:5.4: support them in the next world.”
